review.title: Some Experimental Issues in Financial Fraud Detection: An Investigation
review.abstract: Financial fraud detection is an important problem with a number of design aspects to consider. Issues such as algorithm selection and performance analysis will affect the perceived ability of proposed solutions, so for auditors and re-searchers to be able to sufficiently detect financial fraud it is necessary that these issues be thoroughly explored. In this paper we will revisit the key performance metrics used for financial fraud detection with a focus on credit card fraud, critiquing the prevailing ideas and offering our own understandings. There are many different performance metrics that have been employed in prior financial fraud detection research. We will analyse several of the popular metrics and compare their effectiveness at measuring the ability of detection mechanisms. We further investigated the performance of a range of computational intelligence techniques when applied to this problem domain, and explored the efficacy of several binary classification methods.

sections.heading: A. Algorithms
sections.text: GA2 - An advanced version of GA1 that can use either the best rule as the basis for the next generation or the entire rule set. ACO - A model of an ant colony with rules that represent the path a single ant will follow. NN1 - An incrementally generated neural network that uses distance weighting to construct its hidden neurons. NN2 - An iterative network that presents its neurons as learning vectors. SVM - A light variant of a typical support vector machine with parameterized support vectors. FL - A fuzzy rule learner based on the RIPPER algorithm.

sections.heading: B. Dataset
sections.text: The UCSD-FICO Data Mining Contest 2009 credit card data set used in this search consists of 10,000 samples, 334 numerical input attributes and two output classes for fraudulent and legitimate conduct. Like other fraud data sets, the UCSD data set consists of highly unbalanced data, with only 9% representing fraudulent transactions.

sections.text: Since each fold is a subset of the same dataset, large variations in the results between the folds can indicate higher sensitivity to minor changes in the data, which is a desirable feature in a complicated problem such as detecting financial fraud. Precision showed the largest standard deviation from any metric, most likely as another consequence of the unbalanced nature of the dataset, leading to greater variance in the metrics they analyze. Since this imbalance is typical of the problem of detecting financial fraud, precision is probably an excellent metric for evaluating algorithm performance. In addition, we can see that the optimization of the colony and the two neural networks all tend to a higher standard deviation over metrics than other methods. Specifically, NN2 had the highest of all methods that examine sensitivity and 0.071 for specificity.
